title: 114_hr3484
content: The Act titled "Los Angeles Homeless Veterans Leasing Act of 2016" authorizes certain leases at the Department of Veterans Affairs West Los Angeles Campus. The Act authorizes leases at the Department of Veterans Affairs West Los Angeles Campus for supportive housing and services benefiting veterans and their families. The Act authorizes leases at the Department of Veterans Affairs West Los Angeles Campus for supportive housing and services benefiting veterans and their families, including promotion of health and wellness, education, vocational training, peer activities, legal assistance, volunteerism, family support services, transportation, and services supporting these purposes. The Regents, a corporation under California law representing UCLA, may lease property at the VA West Los Angeles Campus for veteran services, subject to certain conditions. The Regents, representing UCLA, can lease property at the VA West Los Angeles Campus for veteran services that benefit veterans and their families, including those who are severely disabled, women, aging, or homeless. The activities may include medical, clinical, therapeutic, dietary, rehabilitative, legal, mental, spiritual, physical, recreational, research, and counseling needs. The Regents must maintain records documenting the value of the additional services and support provided. The Secretary must maintain records of the additional services provided at the VA West Los Angeles Campus under the lease. Land-sharing agreements must offer health-care resources to the Campus and benefit veterans and their families. Revenues from leases are credited to the Department's medical facilities account for use without fiscal year limitation. The Secretary may grant easements for public transportation facilities at the VA West Los Angeles Campus, without fiscal year limitation or further appropriation. The Secretary may grant easements for public utilities in the City of Los Angeles or any agency for improvements subject to specified conditions. Easements will be terminated upon abandonment or nonuse, with land reverting to the United States. The Secretary may not sell or convey fee simple title to any property at the Campus. Leases must align with the approved master plan. Non-compliance with Federal laws on leases and land use will be investigated by the Inspector General. The Secretary is prohibited from selling or transferring property at the Campus and leases must align with the approved master plan. Non-compliance with Federal laws on leases and land use will be investigated by the Inspector General. If significant mismanagement is found, no new leases or renewals can be made until all recommendations are implemented. The Secretary must establish a Community Veterans Engagement Board within 180 days to coordinate with the Department of Veterans Affairs for the Campus. The Board will identify community goals and provide recommendations to improve services for veterans and their families. The Board overseeing the Community Veterans Engagement Board must have at least 50 percent veterans as members, with the rest being family members, advocates, service providers, or stakeholders. They must collaborate with the community, focus on local issues, and conduct public forums on the Campus. Congressional notification is required for each lease. The Secretary must notify Congress 45 days before entering into or renewing any lease or land-sharing agreement at the Campus. Additionally, an annual report must be submitted to the Senate and House Committees on Veterans' Affairs. The Committee on Veterans' Affairs of the Senate, the Committee on Veterans' Affairs of the House of Representatives, and relevant Members of Congress must receive an annual report evaluating all leases and land-sharing agreements at the Campus, including revenue management and specified records. Additionally, the Inspector General of the Department of Veterans Affairs must submit reports at two and five years after the enactment of the Act, and as deemed necessary thereafter. The Inspector General must submit annual reports to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs and relevant Members of Congress regarding all leases and land management at the Campus, including efforts to implement the master plan. The General must consider the most recent report submitted to Congress by the Secretary. This section does not limit the Secretary's authority to enter into other agreements related to the Campus. "Principally benefit veterans and their families" means services exclusively for veterans and their families or designed for their specific needs. The text discusses services intended for veterans and their families, with any benefit to the general public being secondary. It also excludes services that only generate revenue for the Department of Veterans Affairs. Additionally, there are conforming amendments related to property disposal and enhanced-use leases. The amendment excludes enhanced-use leases under the Los Angeles Homeless Veterans Leasing Act of 2016 from certain provisions in title 38, United States Code.
